title: Kydd Jones Hip Hop Concert
body:
Austin's own Kydd Jones is back again with Austin Public Library for a special live music performance. Celebrate Black History Month with us!

About the performer:

Kydd Jones is a trailblazing singer-songwriter, producer, designer, and emcee born and raised in Austin, Texas who seamlessly blends the raw energy of rock and hip-hop with the essence of R&B and jazz. Jones has performed at festivals like the Billboard Hot 100 Fest, Austin City Limits Music Festival and the Brooklyn Hip-Hop Festival. In 2022, Kydd released his new album, Onyx D'Or and was honored in Austin, Texas by having September 1 declared Kydd Jones Day.

title: Weeknight Cinema: Connection Chronicles
body: Nora and Hae Sung, two deeply connected childhood friends, are wrest apart after Nora's family emigrates from South Korea. Two decades later, they are reunited in New York for one fateful week as they confront notions of destiny, love, and the choices that make a life.

title: Get Crafty: Perler Beads
body: Create pixel art from plastic beads that fuse together when melted with an iron. This month’s theme is Year of the Dragon and we will be watching How to Train Your Dragon!

title: Weeknight Cinema: Connection Chronicles
body: After a chance meeting on a train station, a married doctor and a suburban housewife enter into a muted but passionate, and ultimately doomed, love affair.

title: Get Crafty: Mosaics
body: Make mosaic piece inspired by the art of Alma Thomas.

title: Kids Create
body: Join us for a special Kids Create with guest Mrs. Raley from Casis! She will talk to us about an important artist, Jacob Lawrence, who painted urban landscapes and important figures or moments from history. Then we will make our own cityscapes based on his style out of construction paper and glue.

title: Art in Cahoots: A Pop-Up Arts Experience for Caregivers and Kids
body:
The Ruiz Library is partnering with The Dougherty Arts Center to host Art in Cahoots!

Art in Cahoots activities are free, led by an Austin Artist, and designed specifically for children ages 2.5-5 years of age working cooperatively with an accompanying adult caregiver. This is a great way to collaborate creatively with your child and connect with your community through the arts!

Registration opens on March 8th at 10am. Spots are limited, so register in advance to save your spot.

title: Simplify Your Life Through Organizations
body: Reflect on what's most important in your life, how to save time and money, and find peace in downsizing. With an overview of the Steps to Simplicity downsizing process, learn to connect challenges, priorities, and visualization of your new and improved space, gaining the tools to process independently.

title: Audubon Society Talk
body: What is a bird looking for, when it decides your yard is a good place for a drop-in visit or long-term stay? Just like humans, birds need food, water, shelter, and places to raise young safely, to thrive. Learn how to attract a diversity of expected backyard species, using native plants, water features, supplemental feeders, and nestboxes.  Your yard will come alive with bird song and activity!

title: Free Tax Aid from AARP
body:
If you need assistance to prepare your taxes, we've got you covered. AARP membership is not required. 

No income restrictions for simpler returns.

Make sure you bring the following:

• Photo ID
• Social Security for each person on return
• Tax documents for current year
• Copy of last year's return

Make and appointment here: https://bit.ly/48LIkPE

title: Tween Hardware Coding Club: 4 Week Series
body:
Welcome to our Tween Hardware Coding Club, where we introduce young learners to the fascinating world of coding and hardware through engaging hands-on experiences. Our club uses BBC micro:bits, pocket-sized computers that introduce a practical and fun approach to coding and hardware manipulation. Over the course of the program, students will have the opportunity to bring classic games and gadgets to life. They will create examples such as Magic 8-ball, Rock-paper-scissors, and snake.

Reserved for Ages 8-12. Space is limited. Open to all, but pre-registration reserves you a spot in this 4-week series.

  • Classes are 10:30-11:30 AM at the Central Library 3rd Floor Children's Room
  • Saturdays, 1/6, 1/13, 1/27, 2/3

Note: Children under age 10 must have a parent or guardian remain nearby during the program. Seating will be available near the program room.

title: Virtual Graphic Novel Book Club Jr.
body: We know there are many graphic-novel-devouring tweens out there, so come join Leslie and Heather in discussing books each month. In March, we'll be reading Hilo volume 1: The Boy Who Crashed to Earth by Judd Winick. Friends DJ and Gina are having just another day when a strange boy falls out of the sky. Now they must discover his identity and help him save the world before it's too late.

title: Virtual Graphic Novel Book Club
body:
In March, we'll be reading Deadly Class Volume 1: Reagan Youth by Rick Remender and Wesley Craig. Marcus Lopez is just your typical moody teen who hates his life in 1987. Well, maybe not so typical, considering he goes to a school with the kids of world-class assassins. Damaged teens are even more difficult to deal with when they're being trained to kill and all have weapons.

Registration closes at noon on Monday, March 11.

Please note that due to the nature of the class, attendance is very limited and the program is first come, first served.

title: Stars & Science Planetarium Show
body:
Experience the wonders of the night sky from inside Stars and Science Austin's Discovery Dome.  See the stars, the moon, and the planets inside an inflatable dome.  A trained astronomy educator will lead the Totality Over Texas program.  This program will include discussion about the upcoming total eclipse on April 8th.

Planetarium shows are recommended for ages 3 and up.  Younger children are only allowed with a parent or guardian.

First come, first served.  Space will be limited

Spanish show available at the Southeast Branch.

Disfrute de las maravillas del cielo nocturno desde el interior del Discovery Dome de Stars and Science Austin. Vea las estrellas, la luna y los planetas dentro de una cúpula inflable. Un profesor de astronomía dirigirá el programa Totality Over Texas. Este programa incluirá una discusión sobre el próximo eclipse total el 8 de abril.

Los espectáculos del planetario están recomendados para mayores de 3 años. Los niños más pequeños sólo pueden entrar acompañados de un adulto.

Cupo limitado.

Espectáculo en español disponible en la Biblioteca Southeast (5803 Nuckols Crossing Rd, Austin, TX 78744)

title: Family Archiving Workshop
body:
Have you thought about how to pass down your family’s legacy? 

Documents, photos, diaries, letters, artifacts… Which ones should be saved, and how?

This workshop will cover basic archival preservation techniques. Attendees will learn how to start a family archive, organize artifacts, use preservation techniques, and communicate with loved ones about preserving family history. You are encouraged to bring an item and share its connection to your family’s story. We will learn about each other's histories and tips to preserve the shared items.  

Participants will receive materials to take home to help start their own archiving projects using the tips learned in the workshop. 

*Austin History Center is the local history division of the Austin Public Library.

title: Elizabeth Kahura
body:
Join us in celebration of Black History Month with Elizabeth Kahura, Kenyan born storyteller, drummer, dancer, and teacher of a diverse range of African traditions.

ARTIST BIO:

Elizabeth Kahura is a native of Kenya East Africa. Living in the United States since 1995, she has shared the African beat with audiences of all ages through the African Safari program. As a teacher, storyteller and performer Elizabeth strives to educate and engage her audience through storytelling, puppetry, music, language arts, and hands on art projects. Schools, libraries, museums, and festivals enjoy her inspirational countenance, her displays of African artifacts, and her ability to build a bridge of understanding by demonstrating the similarities between cultures and traditions of Africa and United States. Concepts like the power to dream, character development, and self-empowerment come to life during the performances.

title: Elizabeth Kahura
body:
Join us in celebration of Black History Month with Elizabeth Kahura, Kenyan born storyteller, drummer, dancer, and teacher of a diverse range of African traditions.

ARTIST BIO:

Elizabeth Kahura is a native of Kenya East Africa. Living in the United States since 1995, she has shared the African beat with audiences of all ages through the African Safari program. As a teacher, storyteller and performer Elizabeth strives to educate and engage her audience through storytelling, puppetry, music, language arts, and hands on art projects. Schools, libraries, museums, and festivals enjoy her inspirational countenance, her displays of African artifacts, and her ability to build a bridge of understanding by demonstrating the similarities between cultures and traditions of Africa and United States. Concepts like the power to dream, character development, and self-empowerment come to life during the performances.

title: Downtown Austin Community Court
body:
Downtown Austin Community Court (DACC)

Mobile Court Services

DACC is bringing court services to community spaces across Austin to make it easier to check court case statuses, resolve cases and/or warrants and provide connections to DACC’s homeless services.

 

Services will include:

· Complimentary checks for any open DACC and/or Austin Municipal Court cases or warrants

· Onsite services to resolve outstanding cases and/or warrants (first come, first served based on capacity)

· Information about DACC’s homeless services

 

You will not be arrested for outstanding cases or warrants when engaging with DACC Mobile Court Services or coming to DACC’s office to resolve cases or engage in homeless services.

title: Virtual Graphic Novel Book Club
body:
In February, we'll be reading Last On His Feet: Jack Johnson and the Battle of the Century by Adrian Matejka and Youssef Daoudi. Following legendary boxer Jack Johnson as he fights the Battle of the Century in 1910 while recounting the rest of his life in this historical graphic biography.

Registration closes at noon on Monday, February 12.

title: All Ages Lego Lab
body:
Con Legos, puedes construir cualquier cosa que puedas imaginar y contar cualquier historia que puedas imaginar. ¡Ven al Laboratorio Lego para escuchar, ver, hacer y crear diferentes historias, todo mientras construyes con Legos proporcionados por la Biblioteca! La duración del programa puede variar; llame a la sucursal para obtener más detalles.

Todas las edades son bienvenidas.

title: ArtSmart Storytime: Cherry Blossoms
body: In Japan, the Cherry Blossom Festival is traditionally celebrated in the month of March. How did this celebration travel to the United States to be honored in Washington D.C.? Through stories, learn about this lovely tradition, and then make your own cherry blossom art!

title: Inclusive Low-Stimulation Storytime
body: This inclusive, abbreviated storytime is designed for early learners who benefit from reduced sensory input, including children with special needs.

title: Preschool Imagination Station
body: Designed for young learners, Imagination Station encourages learning through play. Explore the arts, practice your motor skills, and start your STEM exploration. Recommended for ages 2-5.

title: Maker Movie Sing-a-long
body: Join us for a craft, singing, and movie magic that's fun for the whole family. Feel free to sing along with the film, dance a little, and even come in costume as we celebrate the greatest love story of all time!

title: Old Quarry Gardening Group
body:
Whether you're new to gardening or have a green thumb, meet other gardening enthusiasts each month to discuss all things growing. Never grown a thing, but interested in hearing about other's gardens? All are welcome! Come to a meet up to suggest activities to do at future gardening club meet ups.

This month, City of Austin's Education Forester Keith Babberney will teach you how to care for trees year-round.

title: Budgeting Workshop with Business Community Lenders / Taller de Presupuesto
body:
The ESB-MACC Holistic Wellness Program invites you to learn how to manage your finances like a pro! Email us at maccwellness@austintexas.gov to pre-register.

What is your money personality and how does it affect your daily finances?

Learn how to track your expenses and create a spending plan to start an emergency fund or prepare for large purchases.

Library programs and workshops reflect the creative endeavors and diverse interests of the Austin community.

Recommended for ages 18 and up

Classes are bilingual (Spanish)

The Holistic Wellness Program attends to the needs of the total person while remaining rooted in our Latino/Mexican American cultural identities. True wellness is a combination of Physical, Social, Environmental, Financial, Intellectual, Emotional/Mental, Occupational, and Spiritual aspects and, like the diversity of our people, deserves to be nourished and cultivated to enrich individual lives and up.

*****************************************************************************************************************************

Taller de Presupuesto con Business Community Lenders of Texas

El Programa de Salud Holística del ESB-MACC te invita a aprender a manejar sus finanzas como un professional! Envíenos un email  a maccwellness@austintexas.gov para registrarse.

¿Cuál es su personalidad monetaria y cómo afecta a sus finanzas diarias? Aprenda a hacer un seguimiento de sus gastos y a crear un plan de gastos para tener un fondo de emergencia o prepararse para grandes compras. Se requiere pre-registro. Facilitado por Business Community Lenders of Texas.

El Programa de Salud Holística atiende las necesidades de la persona en su totalidad mientras permanece enraizado en nuestras identidades culturales latinas/mexicoamericanas. La verdadera salud es una combinación de aspectos físicos, sociales, ambientales, financieros, intelectuales, emocionales/mentales, ocupacionales y espirituales y, al igual que la diversidad de nuestra gente, merece ser nutrido y cultivado para enriquecer las vidas individuales y elevar a nuestra comunidad.

title: Kydd Jones Hip Hop Concert
body:
Austin's own Kydd Jones is back again with Austin Public Library for a special live music performance. Celebrate Black History with us!

About the performer:

Kydd Jones is a trailblazing singer-songwriter, producer, designer, and emcee born and raised in Austin, Texas who seamlessly blends the raw energy of rock and hip-hop with the essence of R&B and jazz. Jones has performed at festivals like the Billboard Hot 100 Fest, Austin City Limits Music Festival and the Brooklyn Hip-Hop Festival. In 2022, Kydd released his new album, Onyx D'Or and was honored in Austin, Texas by having September 1 declared Kydd Jones Day.

title: Robots and More!
body:
Come learn about robots! Watch a robot in action, explore hands on STEM activities and discover what robotics teams do.

In partnership with robotics team Steel Synergy 23580 and STEM Stride.

title: Spring Break Robotics Camp
body:
Sign up for this Spring Break Robotics Camp for 5th-8th graders held from 1-3pm Monday, March 11- Friday, March 15. You will learn how to build and program a robot while working as a team to solve challenges together. This program gives you an introduction into what it is like to be on a robotics team and how the First Lego League Challenge works.

This event is for children 9-14 years of age.

In partnership with robotics team Steel Synergy 23580 and STEM Stride.

title: Cuentos en pijama (virtual)
body:
Compartimos cuentos, canciones, y rimas en español para enriquecer las habilidades de alfabetización temprana que ayudaran a sus hijos a tener éxito en la escuela. Estos programas están diseñados para niños de 0 a 5 anos.

We share stories, songs, and rhymes in Spanish to enrich early literacy skills that will help your children succeed in school. These programs are designed for children ages 0 to 5.

title: Tween Code Club
body:
Learn to code games and animation in Scratch in this multi-week series on Sundays 1-2:30 at the Little Walnut Creek branch.

Utilizing the Rasberry Pi Code Club curriculum, students will be introduced to the Scratch coding platform, create fun projects, and explore coding concepts such as scripts, loops, operators, and variables. No experience is necessary, all levels are welcome. Please ensure you register for all sessions in a series.

Aprenda a codificar los juegos y las animaciónes en Scratch en esta serie de varias semanas los domingos 1-2:30 en Little Walnut Creek Branch.

Utilizando el plan de estudios de Rasberry Pi, los estudiantes serán introducidos en la plataforma de codificación de Scratch, crearán proyectos divertidos y explorarán conceptos de codificación como scripts, bucles, operadores y variables. No es necesario tener experiencia, todos los niveles son bienvenidos. Asegúrese de registrarse para todas las sesiones de una serie.

title: Free Tax Aide from AARP
body:
If you need assistance to prepare your taxes, we've got you covered. AARP membership is not required. 

No income restrictions for simpler returns.

Make sure you bring the following:

• Photo ID
• Social Security for each person on return
• Tax documents for current year
• Copy of last year's return

Make and appointment here: https://bit.ly/48LIkPE

title: Teen Time
body: Teens 13-18 are invited to join us on Wednesday and Thursday nights for Teen Time -- we'll break out the gaming systems, play board games, make art, and other activities dreamed up by our crew of teen volunteers. A great place to make new friends or drop in if you're thinking of volunteering at Teen Central in the future, too!

Community Swaps are a space for our community members to meet up, give away items they no longer need, acquire those that they do and participate in sustainable living. Bring it. Trade it. Leave no trace behind.

This month bring your unwanted new or laundered clothes, costumes and accessories to trade. Plus visit our modification station.

  • paper story quilts in the style of Faith Ringgold

title: ArtSmart: Cherry Blossoms
body:
March is the month celebrated in Japan for the traditional Cherry Blossom Festival. How did this celebration travel to the US to be honored in Washington D.C.?

Learn through stories about this lovely tradition. Then make your own Cherry Blossom art. This is a great program for children with parent or grandparent participation.

(recommended for ages 3 and older).

title: Adult Story Hour
body:
Tell a five minute story – truth, fiction, funny, serious, read or memorized, any story about life, fantasy or yourself. New themes each time! Everyone is invited to come and listen or to tell a story. 

Question of identity; A time when you had to question "who am I? and where am I going?" How did you get to a place where you felt you really knew yourself? How has it affected your life and / or the relationships in your life?

title: Caroline Paul
body: Caroline Paul will be in conversation with Virginia Rose -- founder of Birdability. The two will discuss Paul's new book Tough Broad, especially focusing on the chapter spent in Austin with the members of Birdability. Books will be available for purchase at the event.

title: Family Naturalists
body: You are never too young or too old to explore and enjoy nature. Bring your curiosity and creativity as we investigate the natural world. This month's theme is Bugs and More!

title: Black History Month Celebration @ Central - Spoken Word Writing Workshop
body: Join us in the Gallery for an inspiring spoken word event, featuring Christa Brown and Tonee Shelton, as part of the Black Girls Don't Wear Red Lipstick photography exhibition. Delve into a thought-provoking writing workshop where you can pen your personal experiences, connecting them to the themes of empowerment and beauty activism highlighted in the exhibit. Conclude the afternoon by sharing your stories in a supportive environment, celebrating self-expression and the power of breaking stereotypes.

title: Black History Month Celebration @ Central - Live Musical Performance
body:
Join us for a live performance by local singer, Alesia Lani.

Every so often we can experience an artist who has an inherent star quality to them that makes them special, Midwest born, Austin raised soul singer Alesia Lani is one of those rare few. Combining a distinctive soulful voice with electric performances, the southern songbird has put many on alert that she is here to stay. Alesia has the unique ability to write timeless music while seamlessly moving across multiple genres including r&b, soul, funk, rock, and hip-hop. Her 'Self Titled' album is a true reflection of her dynamic ability to cross borders while still maintaining her own sound and style. Alesia will be following 'Self Titled' with a lo-fi r&b album in the beginning of 2024 where she will continue to prove to the world that you can't put her musical versatility inside any box.

title: African Drums with Elizabeth Kahura
body:
Join us in celebration of Black History Month with Elizabeth Kahura, Kenyan born storyteller, drummer, dancer, and teacher of a diverse range of African traditions.

ARTIST BIO:

Elizabeth Kahura is a native of Kenya East Africa. Living in the United States since 1995, she has shared the African beat with audiences of all ages through the African Safari program. As a teacher, storyteller and performer Elizabeth strives to educate and engage her audience through storytelling, puppetry, music, language arts, and hands on art projects. Schools, libraries, museums, and festivals enjoy her inspirational countenance, her displays of African artifacts, and her ability to build a bridge of understanding by demonstrating the similarities between cultures and traditions of Africa and United States. Concepts like the power to dream, character development, and self-empowerment come to life during the performances.

title: Emergency Preparedness Pop-Up
body:
Join Austin's Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Management at one of our monthly Emergency Preparedness Pop-Ups at a public library near you!

Austin's Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Management (HSEM) hosts monthly pop-up events at branches of the Austin Public Library. HSEM invites other city departments and non-government organizations to the pop-ups to promote public awareness and provide safety tips to prepare for various emergencies. 

Preparedness materials and other presenters may be catered to highlight and educate on specific emergencies that may be more likely strike the area of that month's event, like wildfire or flooding.

The first 25 attendees receive a basic emergency preparedness kit (limit one per household).

title: For the Love of Books Club
body: Avoid the stress of tracking down a specific book that everyone else wants and getting it read on time. The For the Love of Books Club is a NO HOMEWORK sort of book club. Join fellow Book Lovers to discuss the books you’re already reading and learn about others you should add to your TBR list. Eat snacks, talk books - It's the easiest book club you will ever join! Meets at the Old Quarry branch on the first Wednesday of the month from 2PM to 3PM and on the third Monday from 6:30-7:30PM. Due to holidays, there are a few exceptions throughout the year, so please double check the date you sign up for.

title: Dungeons & Dragons for Teens - 8 Week Campaign
body:
Want to "level up" your Dungeons & Dragons skills? Join this eight-week D&D workshop to learn more about character building, teamwork, problem solving, and combat strategy. We'll grow together from Level 1 as we tackle missions of increasing difficulty... all in the name of fun, glory, and treasure!

Email Leslie.Flynn@austintexas.gov to register. Please note that seating is very limited. All participants are expected to attend at least 7 of the 8 sessions or their spot will be given to someone on the waitlist.

body: Have you been vowing forever to write your story? Our Writing Workshop series with legendary Austin writer, Spike Gillespie, will get you started. You'll feel safe, inspired, and eager to write. In short: You'll be so glad you joined us.

title: Tween Hardware Coding Club: 4 Week Series
body:
Welcome to our Tween Hardware Coding Club, where we introduce young learners to the fascinating world of coding and hardware through engaging hands-on experiences. Our club uses BBC micro:bits, pocket-sized computers that introduce a practical and fun approach to coding and hardware manipulation. Over the course of the program, students will have the opportunity to bring classic games and gadgets to life. They will create examples such as Magic 8-ball, Rock-paper-scissors, and snake.

Reserved for Ages 8-12. Space is limited. Open to all, but pre-registration reserves you a spot in this 4-week series.

  • Classes are 10:30-11:30 AM at the Central Library 3rd Floor Children's Room
  • Saturdays, 1/6, 1/13, 1/27, 2/3

Note: Children under age 10 must have a parent or guardian remain nearby during the program. Seating will be available near the program room.

title: Adult Lego Night
body: Take a break from the daily grind, using Lego! Practice mindfulness, shift focus, and think creatively. This hands-on activity promotes critical/abstract thinking and STEM / STEAM learning while also providing a space for adults to engage in joyful play.

title: Sock Knitting Clinic at Recycled Reads, a Four-Part Workshop
body:
Join Recycled Reads' Untangled Yarners in this 4-part workshop and learn how to knit socks from top down. This series is open to those who have already mastered the basics of knitting (knit & purl stitches, increasing and decreasing). Knowing how to knit on the round is helpful, but not necessary. 

Please bring your own yarn and tools, whether double point needles or circular 40" needles or longer.

Please note: this is not a "Learn how to knit" class, as you will need to have basic knitting knowledge in order to participate.

title: Tween Code Club
body:
Learn to code games and animation in Scratch in this multi-week series on Sundays 1-2:30 at the Little Walnut Creek branch.

Utilizing the Rasberry Pi Code Club curriculum, students will be introduced to the Scratch coding platform, create fun projects, and explore coding concepts such as scripts, loops, operators, and variables. No experience is necessary, all levels are welcome. Please ensure you register for all sessions in a series.

Aprenda a codificar los juegos y las animaciónes en Scratch en esta serie de varias semanas los domingos 1-2:30 en Little Walnut Creek Branch.

Utilizando el plan de estudios de Rasberry Pi, los estudiantes serán introducidos en la plataforma de codificación de Scratch, crearán proyectos divertidos y explorarán conceptos de codificación como scripts, bucles, operadores y variables. No es necesario tener experiencia, todos los niveles son bienvenidos. Asegúrese de registrarse para todas las sesiones de una serie.

title: Kollective Fusion Exhibit Closing Party!
body:
Join us at the Austin History Center for the Kollective Fusion Exhibit Closing Party! This event is not just a closing celebration; it's a tribute to the 50th Anniversary of Hip Hop, brought to life through the creative lens of local artist and designer Bobby Dixon of Kollective Fusion (AKA KLCTVE Design + Illustration).

For over two decades, Bobby Dixon has captivated audiences with his screen-printed concert posters for local, national, and international hip-hop acts. This exhibit showcases a curated selection of his works, highlighting the vibrant hip-hop culture and its influence on Austin's music scene.

Don't miss this last opportunity to immerse yourself in the artistic journey that Bobby Dixon offers, capturing the essence of hip-hop in every design. The closing event promises an engaging experience with:

  • NickNack setting the mood with rhythmic beats.
  • Live printing demonstrations by Industry, giving you a glimpse into the artistic process.
  • A variety of snacks and refreshments to enjoy as you explore the exhibit.

    Come, witness the intersection of art and music, and bid farewell to an extraordinary exhibit.

title: In/Visible A: The Building of an Asian American Film Community
body:
Opening January 26th, 2024 - July 2nd, 2024, at the Main Gallery (810 Guadalupe St, Austin, TX 78701), this vibrant showcase reveals Austin Asian American Film Festival's (AAAFF) evolution from a small film-centric event to a major cultural arts organization.

In/Visible A provides a comprehensive look into AAAFF's history, featuring photographs, posters, program guides, and other records. The exhibit traces the festival's origins and growth, highlighting its role in amplifying Asian American, Native Hawaiian, and Pacific Islander (AANHPI)voices in Austin's cultural landscape and its emergence as a hub for storytelling and cultural exploration.

This retrospective aims to emphasize the significance of representation in media and the influential role of film in community dialogue. It offers visitors insights into AAAFF's dedication to showcasing diverse AANHPI narratives and its contributions to Austin's cultural diversity.

*Artwork displayed in the top banner was created by Emily Ding

Opening Reception:
An opening reception with food and refreshments is scheduled for Thursday, January 25th, from 6PM - 8PM. A panel discussion will take place from 6:30PM - 7:15PM including:

  • Hanna Huang (Executive Director of the AAAFF, Curator of the exhibition )
  • Curran Nault (Assistant Professor at the Department of Radio-Television-Film, UT Austin)
  • Sona Shah (Equity & Inclusion Program Manager, Parks and Recreation Department, City of Austin).

    Visiting the Exhibit and Opening: In/Visible A is free and open to the public. Admission details and visiting hours are available on our website. For further information on parking, to arrange a visit, please contact the Austin History Center.

title: Tween Code Club
body:
Learn to code games and animation in Scratch in this multi-week series on Sundays 1-2:30 at the Little Walnut Creek branch.

Utilizing the Rasberry Pi Code Club curriculum, students will be introduced to the Scratch coding platform, create fun projects, and explore coding concepts such as scripts, loops, operators, and variables. No experience is necessary, all levels are welcome. Please ensure you register for all sessions in a series.

Aprenda a codificar los juegos y las animaciónes en Scratch en esta serie de varias semanas los domingos 1-2:30 en Little Walnut Creek Branch.

Utilizando el plan de estudios de Rasberry Pi, los estudiantes serán introducidos en la plataforma de codificación de Scratch, crearán proyectos divertidos y explorarán conceptos de codificación como scripts, bucles, operadores y variables. No es necesario tener experiencia, todos los niveles son bienvenidos. Asegúrese de registrarse para todas las sesiones de una serie.

title: Holiday K-pop Dance Party
body: Are you looking for a holiday dance party?  Would you like to try K-pop with your friends? Do you know what bias, comeback, and aegyo actually mean? Learn some K-pop iconic dance moves and cool K-pop terms from ATX KDC, UT Austin's premiere K-pop and modern dance team. Join us for holiday music, dance, games, snacks, and lots more! No experience is needed.

title: Chair Yoga
body:
Presented by the Emma S. Barrientos Mexican American Cultural Center (ESB-MACC) Holistic Wellness Program and AARP.

A gentle form of yoga that can be done while seated in a chair. These modifications make yoga accessible to people with various physical abilities or those who find other types of yoga too challenging.

This class is bilingual: English and Spanish

Una forma suave de yoga que se puede hacer sentado en una silla. Estas modificaciones hacen que el yoga sea accesible para la gente con diferente capacidades físicas o para otros que encuentran las clases de yoga difícil.

La clase es bilingüe: inglés y español.

title: Sock Knitting Clinic at Recycled Reads, a Four-Part Workshop
body:
This is the second session of Recycled Reads' Untangled Yarners 4-part workshop. This series is open to those who have already mastered the basics of knitting (knit & purl stitches, increasing and decreasing). Knowing how to knit on the round is helpful, but not necessary. Please note: this is not a "Learn how to knit" class, as you will need to have basic knitting knowledge in order to participate.

Please bring your own yarn and tools, whether double point needles or circular 40" needles or longer.

We are learning how to knit socks from the top down. Today we will learn how to turn the heel. Participants should come with the cuff completed.

title: Solar Eclipse Viewer DIY Workshop

title: Legal Considerations: Starting a Business and Asset Protection
body: Running a business has risks associated with it. There are simple steps business owners can take to protect their personal and business assets against those risks. This workshop will look at ways to protect assets through business formation decisions, trade secret protection, and appropriate legal documents. It is always better to make some protective decisions early on than to put out fires later.

title: Dungeons & Dragons for Teens - 8 Week Campaign
body:
Want to "level up" your Dungeons & Dragons skills? Join this eight-week D&D workshop to learn more about character building, teamwork, problem solving, and combat strategy. We'll grow together from Level 1 as we tackle missions of increasing difficulty... all in the name of fun, glory, and treasure!

Registration information will be available starting December 4. Please note that seating is very limited. All participants are expected to attend at least 7 of the 8 sessions or their spot will be given to someone on the waitlist.

title: Yoga with Andy
body:
Bilingual Yoga for all levels: a practice that focuses on body awareness and connection with the breath. Aligning our movement with our breath will allow us to connect deeply with our body, mind, and soul. This class offers gentle movement and time for meditation and relaxation. 

Yoga Bilingue para todos los niveles de experiencia: una práctica que se enfoca en traer la atención al cuerpo y a la respiración. Alineando nuestro movimiento con nuestra respiración nos permitirá conectarnos profundamente con nuestro cuerpo, mente y alma. Esta clase ofrece movimiento gentil y tiempo de meditación y relajación.

Please bring a thin yoga mat if you have one and wear comfortable clothes. The Library will have a few mats to share.

body: Calling all jigsaw puzzle lovers! Tired of completing the same puzzle over and over? Build something new together, and bring in your old puzzles to swap.

title: Teens Create: Watercolor Sneaker Art
body: Use our watercolor coloring pages or freestyle with your own design to create unique sneakers (2D only!) with watercolors. Teens ages 12-17 welcome.

title: Black History Month Celebration @ Central - Portrait Workshop
body: Join Angelique Ferrao, a local figurative oil painter, for an artistic adventure at our portrait painting workshop. Delve into the captivating world of portraiture in the inspiring setting of the 6th-floor living room, surrounded by her own exhibit, Everyman, of charcoal sketches. Attendees are invited to unleash their creativity using cardstock, pencils, oil pastels, and hand-held mirrors. Let's paint smiles and create lasting memories together!

title: Exhibition Reception: Black Girls Don't Wear Red Lipstick
body:
Please join us in The Gallery at Central Library for the exhibition opening reception; Meet the artist and curators, spoken word performance by Christa Brown, and music by DJ Lauren Light. 

Step into a world of audacious beauty and empowerment with Black Girls Don't Wear Red Lipstick an exhibition at The Gallery at Austin Central Library featuring the work of Austin photographer Leta Harrison. The show is curated by Keyheira Keys and Whitney Hamilton of _OFCOLOR ATX an Austin arts alliance that has partnered with Austin Public Library and The Library Foundation to present the exhibition and its programs.

In Harrison’s joyous, bold photographic prints, Black women embrace vibrant colors and confidently wear shades of red lipstick. Harrison showcases women using beauty as a form of activism to reclaim their power, challenge oppressive beauty standards, and stifle stereotypes. These powerful images promote positive change, and self-love, and illustrate Black women breaking free of the shackles of conformity.

title: Graphic Novel Gallery Show
body: Help us kick off our month-long display of graphic novel art created by your fellow library patrons! Stop by to drop off your art, admire the submissions, or participate in comic-making activities.

title: Teddy Bear Picnic

title: Stars & Science Planetarium Show
body:
Experience the wonders of the night sky from inside Stars and Science Austin's Discovery Dome.  See the stars, the moon, and the planets inside an inflatable dome.  A trained astronomy educator will lead the Totality Over Texas program.  This program will include discussion about the upcoming total eclipse on April 8th.

Planetarium shows are recommended for ages 3 and up.  Younger children are only allowed with a parent or guardian.

First come, first served.  Space will be limited

Spanish show available at the Southeast Branch.

Disfrute de las maravillas del cielo nocturno desde el interior del Discovery Dome de Stars and Science Austin. Vea las estrellas, la luna y los planetas dentro de una cúpula inflable. Un profesor de astronomía dirigirá el programa Totality Over Texas. Este programa incluirá una discusión sobre el próximo eclipse total el 8 de abril.

Los espectáculos del planetario están recomendados para mayores de 3 años. Los niños más pequeños sólo pueden entrar acompañados de un adulto.

Cupo limitado.

Espectáculo en español disponible en la Biblioteca Southeast (5803 Nuckols Crossing Rd, Austin, TX 78744)

title: Amy Bluemel: Native American Storyteller
body:
Join us for an afternoon of Storytelling with Amy Bluemel! Amy is a registered member of the Chickasaw Nation and will bring a large variety of Native artifacts such as hides, arrows, tomahawks, bead work, rattles, dance shakers, literature, and more. Performing in regalia, she will share some of her language, history, culture, and stories. 

¡Únete a nosotros para una tarde de narración con Amy Bluemel! Amy es un miembro registrado de la Nación Chickasaw y traerá una variedad de artefactos nativos como cueros, flechas, tomahawks, trabajo de cuentas, sonajería, agitadores de baile, literatura y más. Actuando en regalia, compartirá parte de su idioma, historia, cultura e historias.

title: Celebrate Diwali at the Oak Hill Library!
body: Celebrate Diwali at your Library! Join us for a Mini-Ramleela, Ravan’s  Katha Storyteller Performance, DIY card making, and select prizes -  including signed Diwali book giveaways! In partnership with the local non-profit, Peerbagh, who are driven by a single mission—to ignite the spark of imagination and inspire creative confidence while encouraging inclusive storytelling inspired by South-Asian culture and storytelling.

title: Homeschool Community Brainstorm
body:
Homeschool Families are invited to come help the Youth Central Librarians brainstorm ways to support your families in the coming year. Librarians from Children's and Teen Services at Central will be present and want to hear from you about how we can serve you in the coming year. Refreshments and fun community-building activities will be provided. 

Questions or can't make it but want to share ideas? Reach out to kathleen.houlihan@austintexas.gov and suzan.nyfeler@austintexas.gov

title: Canceled - Bookmobile Stop
body: Visit our bookmobile at the Northwest Recreation Center. Sign up for your library card and check out books, movies, and audiobooks.

title: Club de Lectura en Español
body:
Enjoy of good company and join us to discuss the title, A Prueba de Fuego, written by Javier Moro.

body: Astrology is made up of cycles of energies.  Join us for a free monthly discussion to learn how to work with the  astrological energies we're all living in.

body: Celebrate International Games Month and Native American Heritage Month with two TTRPGs designed by Native artist Mercedes "Cibby" Acosta: "what happened?" and "Los Arboles." Recommended for teens and adults due to the horror themes in the games.

title: Butterfly Festival/Festival de las Mariposas
body:
Wing your way to the Southeast Branch Library for our first ever Butterfly Festival, a family event where we will be celebrating the butterfly and its connections to Dia de los Muertos. Take a look at our butterfly habitat where painted lady butterflies are growing, make butterfly crafts, and learn about the butterfly life cycle with Texas Master Naturalists. Then, enjoy crafts and the performance ArtSmart: Skulls and Butterflies, by Ambray Gonzales. 

 

¡Vente de volada a la Biblioteca Southeast para participar y disfrutar de nuestro primer Festival de las Mariposas!

En este evento familiar celebraremos la existencia de las mariposas y aprenderemos sobre su conexión con la celebración del Día de Los Muertos.

Ven a observar cómo crecen en nuestro hábitat de mariposas y aprende sobre su ciclo de vida a través de los Maestros Naturalistas de Texas.

Disfruta también de manualidades y del espectáculo ArtSmart: Calaveras y Mariposas, a cargo de Ambray Gonzalez.

Solar Prep Party!

All supplies free, but first come, first served and quantities are limited.

body: Join us for a movie and perler bead program!  Create pixel art from plastic beads that fuse together when melted with an iron and watch a fun movie.  Movie choice forthcoming!

title: Basic Spanish
body:
Come learn Spanish with the Austin Public Library! This free, virtual class intended for beginners. Topics covered include greetings, basic conversations, the weather, telling time, numbers, Spanish for travel, and commonly used verbs.

Register at the link provided or contact Alicia Niwagaba for more information.

title: Digital Nature Walk
body:
Join us for Digital Nature Walk, where we combine nature and AI software to identify plants and animals found around the Central Library!

Limited number of iPads are available, we will be using Apple Camera's which are embedded on all Apple iPads and iPhones. We will also be using an application called Merlin Bird ID, which is a free application you can download on Google play and Apple App Store.

This program is brought to you by APL Innovate, Austin Public Library’s digital makerspace for content creators and other creatives.

title: Cryptids Unleashed! An Afternoon with Cryptozoologist Ken Gerhard
body: Join renowned cryptozoologist Ken Gerhard at the Cepeda branch library as he delves into the weird world of cryptids. Mr. Gerhard has published six books on cryptozoology, and has appeared on Travel Channel, Science Channel, National Geographic, Syfy, Animal Planet, and the History Channel series The Proof Is Out There.

title: Teen Banned Camp: Bookmark Art and Trivia
body: Teens will be able to test their knowledge of banned books with a lightning round of trivia, and then create a piece of bookmark art representing their thoughts about the freedom of information and the right to read freely.

title: Häxan Screening w/ Live Musical Score
body: Join us for a screening of Häxan, a true classic of the silent horror film genre. Renowned Austin composer and musician David Didonato provides a live score.

title: Canceled - A performance and lecture by Aaron Pyle
body:
Aaron Pyle is a Native American flute player, storyteller, and lecturer whose presentations interweave music with traditional and contemporary tales and is well suited for youth and adult audiences.

Aaron Pyle is a member of the Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma and an active contributor in the Central Texas intertribal community. He holds a Bachelor of Arts in Music and Anthropology from Texas State University, a Master of Science in Social Work from the University of Texas at Austin, and a PhD in Educational Leadership and Policy from the University of Texas at Austin. His research focuses on Native American experiences in education.

title: Yoga with Katherine
body:
Join us for some mindful movement on the 1st Thursday of each month. 

This class will focus on strengthening and stretching the body, cultivating a calm and centered mind and breathing. We will make use of blocks, straps, the wall, and chairs to support healthy alignment and relaxation. Students with all levels of experience are welcome!

Please bring a thin yoga mat if you have one and wear comfortable clothes. The Library will have a few mats to share.

title: Family Movie Matinee
body:
Join us for free popcorn, lemonade, and an afternoon movie!  This month follow Miguel in his journey to the Land of the Dead as he discovers the truth behind his family history in Pixar/Disney's Coco, rated PG. 

Played in English with subtitles in Spanish.

En inglés con subtítulos en español.

title: Dig It: Gardening in Texas
body: This November, Austin Davenport will be teaching us all about soil health! Join us in learning to improve your garden yield and the health of your plants by tending to your soil! Compost, worms, fertilizer, mulch, mushrooms and more ! Transform your soil to grow you most resilient and productive garden, yet!

title: Dinovember Party
body: Join us for a storytime celebration of all things dinosaurs! We've got crafts and learning activities for everyone from Eorapter enthusiasts to Stegaoaurus stans. Learn all about carnivorous dinosaurs with local paleontologist BK Bones at 1PM. Recommended for ages 3 and up.

title: Dinovember Party
body: Calling all dino fans for a party to remember! We've got crafts and learning activities for everyone from Eorapter enthusiasts to Stegaoaurus stans.   Recommended for ages 3 and up.

title: Dinovember with Paleontologist BK Bones
body: Join us for an all-ages show with local paleontologist BK Bones! Learn all about exciting Meat-Eating Dinosaurs. Learn more about your favorites, as well as carnivorous dinos that might be new to you, as well as all their special adaptations that helped them thrive on prehistoric Earth.

title: STEM Craft: Potion Painting
body: Practice painting with different chemical reactions like bubble painting, salt and watercolor, and more.

title: CANCELLED - Well Read Sistahs and Chicas
Roots & Wings Festival Event: It's a Plant Party!
body: Join us for a fun family event for all ages! Activities include a nature scavenger hunt, seedball crafts, plant propagation station, and plant and seed swap.

title: Heartdrum Author Panel for Native American Heritage Celebration
body: BookPeople and Austin Public Library welcome Heartdrum authors Kim Rogers, Brian Young, Laurel Goodluck, Dawn Quigley, and Cynthia Leitich Smith to celebrate Native American Heritage Month as part of APL's full day of music, food and more celebrating the rich heritage of Native Americans.

title: Teen Writing workshop with Brian Lee Young
body: Join author and filmmaker Brian Young in a special limited-size writing workshop, held in Teen Central, our dedicated teen area at the Central Library, as part of our Native American Heritage Month Celebration. Brian will be focusing on revising scenes with goals oriented characters as he leads attendees through guided writing instruction, and shares his knowledge of the craft with teen writers who attend. Brian is an enrolled member of the Navajo Nation, and also represents Heartdrum, an imprint of HarperCollins by Native American authors. Space is limited, so please reserve your spot by claiming a ticket!

title: All Ages Storytime with BK Bones!
body: Celebrate Dinovember with a special dinosaur-themed storytime presented by paleontologist, BK Bones!

body: Visit the library for a day of hands-on science centers, Cretaceous crafts, a pop-up museum, special guest and so much more!

title: Adobe for All: 8- Bit Pixel Portrait
body:
Learn how to make 8-bit Pixel Portraits using Adobe Photoshop.

A﻿dobe for All is a program series created by the Innovate Digital Makerspace at the Central Library. This program was created to teach the basics of various Creative Cloud Applications through short tutorials. The classes are beginner-friendly and open to all ages!

We have 13 Desktop computers, but you are more than welcome to bring your own device if you have Adobe Photoshop already installed.

If tickets are sold out, don't be discouraged, feel free to show up and learn!

Tickets available soon!

body: Join us while we celebrate Banned Book Week and freedom of speech with a night of music, poetry, and expression. You bring your voice and your art, we'll provide a piano, guitar, and microphone.

title: APL After Dark: Creature Feature
body:
Join us at Central Library after hours for an evening where adults 21+ enjoy all things classic horror films. APL After Dark is an adults-only (21+) evening in the Austin Central Library that explores a fun theme. Come out for entertainment, games, storytelling, music, drinks & more — inside your favorite library!

T﻿his October, join us to explore the world of Creature Features, a genre of classic horror films and TV shows filled with every manner of creepy crawler, oversized reptiles, and monsters from swaps, black lagoons, haunted seas, and space. Experience the magic of holographic effects with the Innovation Lab. Spice up your Halloween costume with SFX makeup workshops. Meet new scaly friends with Austin Reptile Show and learn about toxic plants. Get ready for your closeup in the Quick Draw Photo Booth and toss back popcorn and candy like at the movies. Discover nature gone wild in the Central Library!

body: A family storytelling event with La Catrina. Enjoy stories, songs, a shadow puppet show, and crafts. Two performances: 10:15 and 11:15am.

title: Homeschool Day at the Bullock Museum
body:
Enjoy a FREE day full of discovery and learning at the Bullock Museum for homeschool families.

  • 10:30 a.m. – 11:30 a.m. Participate in a special paid class with Central Texas Mycological Society to learn about how mushrooms grow and to make your own mushroom-growing block using recycled materials.
  • 11:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. Join Austin Public Library for a fungi-themed story time.
  • 12:30 p.m. – 1:30 p.m. Join award-winning author Alisha Gabriel to learn all about fungi by dissecting a plush mushroom, building your own fungi-journal, and going on an exciting fungi scavenger hunt to document some unusual fungi you can find in your own neighborhood.

title: Waterloo Greenway Morning Glories
body:
Join us for an unBOOlievably fun and spooky celebration of Halloween and Dia de los Muertos. Read the Room will lead an exploration of bravery and facing our fears through storytelling, movement, and music.

Little hands get hands-on fun at wonder-filled workshops focused on literacy, bilingual storytelling, music and dance, cultural learning, and nature play.

Each week features a different style of play from our partners at Texas Book Festival, Austin Public Library, Armstrong Community Music School, Read the Room, Creative Action, and the Emma S. Barrientos Mexican American Cultural Center.

title: HEB Free First Sunday at the Bullock Museum
body:
Enjoy FREE exhibition admission all day during H-E-B Free First Sundays, held the first Sunday of every month. Activities are from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Families can explore the Story of Texas through three floors of exhibitions that showcase and tell the history of artifacts from around the state.

  • 10:30 a.m. and 11:30 a.m. Join Austin Public Library for storytime and hands-on activities
  • 11:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. Enjoy traditional Puerto Rican dances performed by Puerto Rican Folkloric Dance
  • Learn about Puerto Rican culture through interactive activities, including a Puerto Rican traditional vejigante-inspired mask craft

title: Lone Star Zine Fest
body:
It’s back and it’s spookier than ever! The 7th annual Lone Star Zine Fest will have over 100 vendors slinging zines, comics, art and much more! Plus zinemaking, treats, and door prizes! Visit the Austin Public Library's booth at the Blue Genie Art Bazaar | 6100 Airport Blvd Austin, TX.

The event is FREE and for all ages! Costumes encouraged.

For more information, please visit www.lonestarzinefest.org

title: South Asian Festival
body: Come celebrate Austin’s South Asian culture with talented community artists and dancers! There will be a traditional dance demonstration, Henna artist, art gallery, samosas and much more!

title: Garden Storytime-Roots & Wings
body:
We’re excited to be hosting an official Roots & Wings Festival Event! The Roots & Wings Festival is held from Wednesday, October 18, through Saturday, November 5, and is a community-wide celebration honoring Arbor Day and Monarch Appreciation Day in Austin. Join us in celebrating the Roots & Wings Festival on October 21st with Garden Storytime.

Enjoy a special Roots & Wings storytime, a butterfly craft, and the opportunity to take home your own caterpillar to raise into a butterfly!

title: Central Library Sing-a-long: Holiday Big Sing with Conspirare
body: Grab your friends and family and celebrate the season with Conspirare. Craig Hella Johnson will conduct the Holiday Big Sing, in which the audience is the choir, with help from the Conspirare Symphonic Choir. Come sing your holiday favorites together. No singing experience is needed! Wear your holiday sweater and Santa hat to celebrate or just come as you are.

title: Cardboard Kingdom

Play in our haunted cardboard castle and build a rocket, robot, or a costume-- the only limit is your imagination. Ages 5+ only. Space is limited.

title: Dungeons and Dragons School: Character Creation Tween Edition
body: Tweens! Don't know the difference between a half-elf and a halfling? A wizard or a warlock? Our master Dungeon Master will walk you through the steps of creating your own playable characters. Afterward, put your new character to the test in a quick one-shot game. Each attendee will leave with a set of dice (while supplies last).

Eclipse Party
body: Enjoy space-themed crafts and activities for all ages before exploring the skies and viewing the annular solar eclipse.

title: Bookmobile Stop
body: Visit our bookmobile at the Anderson Mill Senior Center. Sign up for your library card and check out books, movies, and audiobooks.

title: Lounge Movie Night: T﻿he Magic of Méliès
body:
Austin Public Library's Innovate Digital Makerspace invites you to get inspired by films featuring trailblazing artists that paved the way for artistic creation.

T﻿he Magic of Méliès is a documentary about George Méliès, who was one of the first to film fictional narratives, and is regarded as the inventor of special effects in movies. His films were among the first to use such techniques as double exposure, stop-motion, and slow motion.

This recurring event will happen every third Thursday of the month at the Innovation Lounge, stay tuned to see what amazing films we will be presenting next.

Also, find out how you can recreate similar art using our Digital Makerspace, located on the 5th floor of the Austin Central Library!

title: Talk Time
body:
Improve your English conversation. ¡Mejore su conversación en inglés!

Talk Time is a program for English conversation practice with other English language learners and English speaking volunteers. No registration is necessary. The program is open to any adult who speaks some English and wants an informal and safe place to practice with others.

Participe en Talk Time: Hablemos Inglés, un programa gratis de La Biblioteca Pública de Austin, donde usted puede venir a conversar en inglés y así practicar y sentirse más seguro. No es necesario registrarse. Este programa se ofrece a cualquier adulto que hable algo de inglés y que quiera practicarlo con otros en un lugar informal y sin presiones.

title: Mushrooms, Worms and Birds: A Roots and Wings Event
body:
Join us for a day celebrating mushrooms, worms and birds! Central Texas Mycological Society will host their scarecrow mushroom cultivation workshop and bucket tek workshop. Don't forget to register for the bucket tek workshop! Enjoy a presentation by the Travis Audubon Society to learn which native plants attract birds to your yard along with a fun craft activity to take home. Then discover how red wiggler worms help the soil and composting with hands on activities presented by Keep Austin Beautiful throughout the day.

10am-2pm – Keep Austin Beautiful

Wormy Composting

We will bring our vermi-compost bin and youth will have the opportunity to explore the wonders of our red wiggler worms!

10am – Central Texas Mycological Society

Lo-tek Mushroom Cultivation Scarecrow Workshop

Join us for a workshop that combines a bunch of spooktacular things we love about fungi! First, fun with fungi while learning basics of mycoremediation growing mushrooms outdoors, and creating a scarecrow to protect your garden. Since it’s okay to decay, we will be building scarecrow together that will decompose over the fall and winter with the help of recycled oyster mushroom blocks.

11am – Travis Audubon Society

Gardening for Birds with Native Plants

Do you want to attract more birds to your yard or neighborhood greenbelt? In this talk you will find out how native plants help birds, and get acquainted with several easy to grow native plants that appeal to birds and other wildlife.

12pm - Central Texas Mycological Society

Bucket tek Workshop (Registration Required)

Learn how to recycle mushroom blocks to build healthy soil, sequester carbon, increase water retention and divert organic matter from the waste stream. *The Bucket tek Workshop requires registration and for you to bring your own container.* Registration Link here: AUSTIN: Mushrooms, Worms, and Birds! A Roots & Wings Event — Central Texas Mycological Society (centraltexasmycology.org)

title: Star Weaving with One Million Stars Texas
body:
One Million Stars Texas is part of One Billion Stars, a global star weaving project that invites communities around the world to weave these symbols of light, courage and solidarity for violence free communities. Building community connections and creating a safe sense of belonging is the heart of our star weaving movement.

In this workshop we will share information about the One Million Stars Texas project and participants will learn how to weave an 8 pointed star. This intergenerational project is a great activity for the whole family. All supplies will be provided.
 

Recommended for ages 10 and up

title: Youth Native American Heritage Month Celebration
body: November is National Native American Heritage Month. Spicewood Springs Branch has invited Dr. Aaron Pyle to share about Native Americans and Tribes around the central United States. Dr. Pyle, a member of the Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma, will feature stories told over many years accompanied by music from his flute. Experience and learn as a family! Coloring activities and snacks will be provided in this along with Dr. Pyle's presentation!

title: Austin Studio Tour: Barbara Attwell

title: All Ages Native American Heritage Month Celebration
body: November is National Native American Heritage Month. Menchaca Road Branch has invited Dr. Mario Garza and the Aztec Dance Company - Mitotiliztli Yaoyollohtli to share about Native Americans and Tribes around the central United States. Dr. Garza, an elder of the Miakan/Garzas Band of the Coahuiltecan, a state-legislature-recognized tribe of Texas, will discuss eye opening facts about Native innovations and ancient contributions. Mitotiliztli Yaoyollohtli is a family of Danzantes and relatives from the Dallas area that feature and teach Danza steps while conveying a deep sense of cultural understanding. Audience participation is voluntary. Coloring activities and snacks will also be provided in this afternoon of discovery and learning!

title: Dinosaur or NOT? presented by BK Bones
body: Families and friends are invited to join us for a night of paleontological fun! BK Bones connects with kids through questions, exploration and creativity. Expect eye-catching images, fossils (and fossil replicas) and lots of high-energy interaction as we figure out which prehistoric animals were dinosaurs and which were NOT.

title: Discover Your Family’s Story
body: Join us for a genealogy seminar at the Pleasant Hill Public Library! Discover your family's history and learn how to trace your roots. This staff led workshop will teach you how to use Austin Public Library’s online genealogy resources to explore your family history. Whether you're a beginner or an experienced researcher, this event is perfect for anyone interested in exploring their ancestry. Our knowledgeable instructor will guide you through the fascinating world of genealogy, providing tips and tricks to help you uncover your family's past. Don't miss this opportunity to connect with your heritage and uncover the stories that make you who you are. Mark your calendars and join us for Discover Your Family's Story at the Pleasant Hill Public Library!

title: Preparing for & Connecting During the Holidays
body:
Join the Capital of Texas' Alzheimer's Association for a talk for families living with Alzheimer's or other dementias, the holidays can be stressful and challenging.  Festivities can agitate or confuse individuals with the disease, and care partners can be overwhelmed by trying to maintain traditions.  However, with planning and adjusted expectations, seasonal celebrations can still be joyous and meaningful.  

Join us to learn tips for managing the holiday season and connecting, communicating, and celebrating at each stage of the disease.  Topics covered include:

  • Modifying celebrations
  • Supporting the caregiver
  • Considerations for in-person gatherings
  • Communication tips

title: Lounge Movie Night: How Video Games Changed the World
body:
Austin Public Library's Innovate Digital Makerspace invites you to get inspired by films featuring trailblazing artists that paved the way for artistic creation.

How Videogames Changed the World is a one-off television special by Charlie Brooker which was aired on Channel 4 in November 2013. The show examines the 25 most significant video games according to Brooker, and through that, covers the history of the medium and its impact on wider culture.

This recurring event will happen every third Wednesday of the month at the Innovation Lounge, stay tuned to see what amazing films we will be presenting next.

Also, find out how you can recreate similar art using our Digital Makerspace, located on the 5th floor of the Austin Central Library!

title: Weeknight Cinema: Workers' Walkouts
body: In turn-of-the-twentieth century Turin, an accident in a textile factory incites workers to stage a walkout. But it's not until they receive unexpected aid from a traveling professor that they find a voice, unite, and stand up for themselves. This historical drama by Mario Monicello is a beautiful and moving ode to the power of the people, brimming with humor and honesty.

title: Weeknight Cinema: Workers' Walkouts
body: Written and directed by John Sayles, this wrenching historical drama recounts the true story of a West Virginia coal town where the local miners' struggle to form a union rose to the pitch of all-out war in 1920. When Matewan's miners go on strike, organizer Joe Kenehan (Chris Cooper, in his film debut), arrives to help them, uniting workers white and black, Appalachia-born and immigrant, while urging patience in the face of the coal company's violent provocations.

title: Movie Night: Smoke Signals
body:
Join us on Wednesday November 15th at 6pm at Milwood Branch Library for a screening of Smoke Signals (1998) in honor of Native American Heritage Month. Smoke Signals was the first feature film written, directed, and produced by Native Americans. The film won the Filmmaker’s Trophy for director Chris Eyre, a member of the Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribal Nations, and the Audience Award at the 1998 Sundance Film Festival. The film was also selected for preservation in the National Film Registry for being “culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant". 

The runtime is 89 minutes. The event is free and open to the public.

title: Virtual Graphic Novel Book Club
body:
In November, we'll be reading Lore Olympus volume 1 by Rachel Smythe. Persephone has finally convinced her mother to let her move to Olympus to start college after growing up in the mortal realm. Now she's thrown into a world of gods and goddesses, and when she meets Hades, god of the Underworld, she's really gets herself into trouble. Volume 1 includes chapters 1 through 25 of the Webtoons comic.

Registration closes at noon on Monday, November 13.

title: Audubon Society Presentation
body: Have you ever visited a local lake and wondered what ducks and wading birds you are seeing? Have you noticed that the number and diversity of species changes throughout the year? Ducks and herons are big and easier to see than songbirds, and identifying them on your own can be satisfying and fun. Some birds that look like ducks, but aren’t ducks, will be included.

title: The Crafty Adult: Dreamcatchers are Not Your Aesthetic
body:
Originating with the Ojibwe of the North, Dreamcatchers are an item of spiritual and cultural significance to Native Peoples across North America. Today, corporations and companies around the world have appropriated these sacred hoops in an effort to profit from our traditions. People have forgotten the stories and meanings behind Dreamcatchers and use them in inappropriate ways. Join North Village and the Austin History Center for this workshop, we will share the stories, spiritual significance, and meanings behind the Dreamcatcher and you will learn respectfully how to make one for yourself or a loved one.

Registration is required.  Supplies will be limited.

title: Artist Talk with Kollective Fusion
body:
Artist Talk with Kollective Fusion: Coinciding with the 50th year of Hip Hop, APLs first hip-hop-themed poster exhibition will be traveling from the Austin History Center to multiple branches throughout the Austin Public Library. The hip hop poster artist, founder of KLCTIVE and Creative Director at Industry Print Shop, Bobby Dixon will share his insights and creation ideas of his work with attendees. Come mingle with the artist and other hip hop art enthusiasts!

About the Exhibit
The Bobby Dixon Kollective Fusion Poster Exhibition: Celebrating Hip Hop Through Artistry and Design

This exhibition celebrates the 50th Anniversary of Hip Hop through the work of local artist and designer Bobby Dixon of Kollective Fusion (AKA KLCTVE Design + Illustration)

March 26, 2024 - May 23, 2024

Ruiz Branch - 1600 Grove Blvd.

About the Artist

Literacy tips and resources for all, and information on how you can take action to combat censorship and book bans from the African American Policy Forum, the American Library Association and others.

Free books and literacy information on the Banned Bookmobile for parents, educators and librarians—get up to 10 free books for classroom collections and school libraries and 5 free books for home libraries.

Astrology Workshop

Astrology is made up of cycles of energies.  Join us for a free monthly discussion to learn how to work with the  astrological energies we're all living in.

title: Spooky Carnival
body:
Celebrate all things spooky and scary at our Halloween Carnival for kids!  Games, crafts, activities and fun for all ages! Costumes encouraged!

Highlights include:

  • Austin Bat Refuge will be bringing live bats to meet and greet!
  • Blood Bar with a different red drink for each blood type!
  • Slime Making!
  • Monster toothpaste!
  • Free Candy! 
  • Halloween Crafts and Outdoor Games!

Everything is while supplies last!

title: Cancelled for Election: Steeped In Books
Jewelry Making with Nan Blassingame
body: Appreciate the beauty of indigenous culture, learn the history of the jingle dress, and make jewelry with fashion designer and Austin Powwow dancer, Nan Blassingame! All materials are provided.

title: Austin Studio Tour: Terri St. Arnauld
body:
Please visit the Twin Oaks Branch any time during open hours* to enjoy artist Terri St. Arnauld's work as part of the Austin Studio Tour.  Her art will be on display at the Twin Oaks Branch from October 31 - November 27, 2023.

https://www.platinumportraitsphoto.com/

2023 Austin Studio Tour

Weekend 1: November 4-5 (WEST of IH-35) 12 – 6pm

Weekend 2: November 11-12 (WEST & EAST) 12 – 6pm

Weekend 3: November 18-19 (EAST of IH-35) 12 – 6pm

*The Twin Oaks Branch is open Monday - Thursday 9 am - 8 pm, Friday 9 am - 5 pm, and Saturday 10 am - 5 pm.  The Austin Public Library will be closed Friday, November 10 & Saturday, November 11 for Veterans Day.

title: Haunted Candyland
body:
Navigate your way through the haunted stacks and enjoy crafts and activities! Treats and candy will also be provided.

 ¡Halloween en la biblioteca!

¡Navega a través de las pilas embrujadas y disfruta de artesanías y actividades! Golosinas y dulces serán proveídos.

title: Access Opera: Pagliacci Docent Presentation
body: Austin Opera is excited to present this lecture to tweens and teens which gives insight into the production of their upcoming performance of "Pagliacci".

title: Canceled - Intermediate Guitar Lessons with Mauricio Callejas
body: Free weekly intermediate guitar lessons. Pre-registration required (Ages 15+): email maccwellness@austintexas.gov to register. Please bring your own guitar. Todas las clases son bilingües - inglés y español.

title: Canceled - Beginner Guitar Lessons with Mauricio Callejas
body: Free weekly beginner guitar lessons. Pre-registration required (Ages 15+): email maccwellness@austintexas.gov to register. Please bring your own guitar. Todas las clases son bilingües - inglés y español.

title: Library Escape Room: Mysteries of the Deep
body:
Dive into the free thrilling Library Escape Room: Mysteries of the Deep, where you'll unravel ancient secrets and solve puzzles in a group. 

While attempting to contact the Great Old One Cthulhu, Professor Freeborn and four of his colleagues have been ripped through a portal to another reality. Now, trapped in the Professor’s office, you and your fellow students must sort through the esoteric clutter to solve the puzzles and find the incantation that will close the portal and save our reality from utter destruction.

Eventbrite tickets for Library Escape Room: Mysteries of the Deep are live. Sign up today with family and friends aged 13+ or go for a mystery group in the same time slot—maximum group size is 10. If all tickets are sold out, you are welcome to come to the library and wait in case there are no shows.

title: Star Weaving with One Million Stars Texas
body:
One Million Stars Texas is part of One Billion Stars, a global star weaving project that invites communities around the world to weave these symbols of light, courage and solidarity for violence free communities. Building community connections and creating a safe sense of belonging is the heart of our star weaving movement.

In this workshop we will share information about the One Million Stars Texas project and participants will learn how to weave an 8 pointed star. Star weaving is a medium level weaving technique and is a great activity to share with friends and family. All supplies will be provided.

Adults only please.

title: Tween Kawaii Club: Flower Octopus Clay Sculpture with Rita Wang
body: Join us for a fun-filled afternoon of creativity at the Tween Kawaii Club event! Get ready to unleash your artistic side and learn the art of clay sculpting with the talented artist, Rita Wang. During this hands-on workshop, you will discover the secrets behind creating adorable flower octopus sculptures. For ages 9-12.

title: Star Weaving with One Million Stars Texas
body:
One Million Stars Texas is part of One Billion Stars, a global star weaving project that invites communities around the world to weave these symbols of light, courage and solidarity for violence free communities. Building community connections and creating a safe sense of belonging is the heart of our star weaving movement.

In this workshop we will share information about the One Million Stars Texas project and participants will learn how to weave an 8 pointed star. This intergenerational project is a great activity for the whole family. All supplies will be provided.

Local Comics Artist/self-publisher, Adam Kobetich will discuss the techniques he has learned from his experience as a Comics artist.

title: Banned Books Silent Reading Party
body: Celebrate your freedom to read at our silent reading party. Bring your favorite book to read or borrow one of our headsets and listen to George Orwells' 1984 or Shirley Jackson's The Lottery on audiobook. Snacks and beverages will be provided while supplies last.

title: Virtual Graphic Novel Book Club
body:
In October, we'll be reading Killadelphia Volume 1: Sins of the Father by Rodney Barnes and Jason Shawn Alexander. When a cop returns home to Philadelphia to bury his detective father, he begins unraveling a mystery that leads to horror and... an undead president?

Registration closes at noon on Monday, October 9.

title: Canceled - Bookmobile Stop
body: Visit our bookmobile at the Northwest Recreation Center. Sign up for your library card and check out books, movies, audio books and more!

title: Blackout Poetry Craftstation
body: Learn about blackout poetry and make your own poem at our Banned Books Craftstation!

title: Banned Camp Film Fest
body: Join us for a screening of a film based on a banned book. We will watch the 2019 documentary about the beloved, yet controversial children horror series Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark. Movie is rated PG-13 and is recommended for ages 13 and up.

title: Banned Camp Film Fest
body: Join us for a screening of a film based on a banned book. Tonight we are showing Are You There God. . . It's Me, Margaret, a film based on Judy Blume's beloved teen classic. Film is rated PG-13 and recommended for ages 13 and up.

title: Banned Camp Film Fest
body: Join us for a family screening and art project to celebrate Banned Books Week. Speak for the trees and come by and watch The Lorax. This book was banned in 1989 from a California Public school for "brainwashing children". This movie is rated PG and is recommended for ages 9 and up.

title: Teen Banned Camp: Representation Matters
body: OutYouth invites all teens who are passionate about the power of books and the importance of representation to join us for an inspiring presentation. Discover how to create your own banned book club.

title: Arts Alive
body: Milwood Branch will be host to local artists as they work on their projects in real time. Come in and meet the local community and talk to the artists about their process and what inspires them to create. Make your own abstract watercolor painting to take with you!

title: Virtual Graphic Novel Book Club Jr.
Teen Banned Camp Film Fest: Persepolis
body: This event is for teens 13-18 only. Join us for a screening of a film based on a banned book. Persepolis, and stick around to discuss the film and the current state of book challenges.

title: Just for Ages 9-12: Tween Council
body: Help your librarians make important decisions, work on a service project that will directly benefit library patrons, and do a fun activity!

title: Banned Book Cricut Station
body: Stop by and make some Banned Book swag with the help of our cricut machine.

title: Banned Book Zine Making
body: Learn to use foam block printing techniques to make a bookmark or bag with a banned book theme.

title: Tween Code Club
body:
Learn to code games and animation in Scratch in this three-week series on Sundays 1-2:30 at the Little Walnut Creek branch.

Utilizing the Rasberry Pi Code Club curriculum, students will be introduced to the Scratch coding platform, create fun projects, and explore coding concepts such as scripts, loops, operators, and variables.  No experience is necessary, all levels are welcome. Please ensure you register for all three sessions in a series.

Aprenda a codificar los juegos y las animaciónes en Scratch en esta serie de tres semanas los domingos 1-2:30 en Little Walnut Creek Branch.

Utilizando el plan de estudios de Rasberry Pi, los estudiantes serán introducidos en la plataforma de codificación de Scratch, crearán proyectos divertidos y explorarán conceptos de codificación como scripts, bucles, operadores y variables. No es necesaria experiencia, todos los niveles son bienvenidos. Asegúrese de registrarse para las tres sesiones de una serie.
